tracks.description:

tracks.description:
David Loebel conducts the New England Conservatory Symphony in a performance of Schubert's  Symphony no 8 in B minor, D 759 "Unfinished". Recorded live February 1, 2012 in NEC's Jordan Hall, Boston.
For more info: http://necmusic.edu
tracks.title: Schubert: Symphony no 8 in B minor, D 759 "Unfinished"-  Allegro moderato

user.description: New England Conservatory educates and trains musicians of all ages from around the world, drawing on the talent and deep reservoir of experience of our distinguished faculty. We are dedicated to inculcating the highest standards of excellence and nurturing individual artistic sensibility and creative growth. Understanding that music is one of the transcendent expressions of human civilization, NEC aspires to ensure it a central place in contemporary society. Additionally, we present over 1,000 free concerts a year in our world class performance spaces which include historic Jordan Hall.

tracks.description: Hugh Wolff conducts the New England Conservatory Philharmonia in a performance of Schubert's Symphony No. 9 in C Major. Recorded live in Jordan Hall November 5, 2014.

user.description:
For Phil, traditional classical piano training was something of a straitjacket. He rebelled from a very young age by teaching himself to improvise and play by ear. Fundamentally gentle by nature - he’s a vegan and life-long meditator - the competitive world of classical piano seemed brutal. Phil plays music simply for the love of it and nothing else matters to him. He’s not interested in definitive interpretations or who-can-play-the-fastest performances: what Phil offers is real musical sense, through delivering rhythm and groove, melody and harmony with depth, clarity and unconventional intelligibility.

Phil plays in a refreshingly unpretentious and accessible way, telling musical stories with vivid, straightforward passion. Being a Yorkshireman, he says it how it is, and music for him is profound solace, catharsis and joy: so this is what he offers. Being extraordinarily fluent in the language of music on the keys, he loves to improvise freely, allowing the music to pour forth spontaneously, from a place of deep body-and-soul consciousness. And he aims to make the music of Mozart, Chopin, Rachmaninov, and every piece he plays, come from this place of real transformation and healing.
